results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film captures some of the highlights of Sydney in 1962 – the harbour and bridge, memorials, gardens, building sites and streets and historic houses, as well as people working, fishing, playing bowls, sailing and catching ferries. There is a focus on traffic and cars around the inner Sydney area such as a wonderful scene of a double decker bus and taxis of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Sydney 1962’
00:00:14:00 a man is wandering around the Sydney University campus
00:01:00:00 views of Sydney whilst driving through traffic
00:01:34:00 Lennox Bridge at Parramatta.
00:01:44:00 a sign for Windsor followed by footage of historic houses
00:03:22:00 Sydney Harbour Bridge and ferry
00:06:31:00 Sydney Anzac Memorial
00:06:46:00 City Bowling Club
00:07:09:00 Sydney ‘El Alamein Memorial Fountain’
00:07:20:00 scenes at ‘Vaucluse House’
00:07:54:00 yachts sailing around the harbour
00:08:38:00 an Ansett seaplane at a pier
00:08:48:00 people fishing of a small pier
00:08:56:00 Sydney double decker bus and taxis
00:10:30:00 Rural Bank of NSW building
00:11:20:00 large excavation at a building site leaving a narrow house standing to the side
00:12:05:00 ferry ‘Kooleen’ followed by scenes shot from a boat or ferry of the harbouside

results.title: Fred's Films. 'Tis Christmas
results.brief_description: Captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker are highlights of a Melbourne family during the mid 1960s. Christmas for Fred included showing the trains of Flinders St and a W-Class Tram in the City of Melbourne, along with the famous ‘Foy’s Corner’, corner of Bourke and Swanston St. There are some amusements in the gardens and some ‘Viking’ boats rowing on the Yarra. A Santa in the back of a truck can only mean the office Christmas party. The family relax at a swimming pool and have a picnic in a bush setting. Back to a brief sequence of a helicopter landing on the helipad on the Yarra River, then there is a road trip. This features some impressive footage from the camera mounted on the car, to the Mornington Peninsula and Rosebud. Fred and the family relax staying at a caravan park at the beach, go water skiing, spend time in paddle boats and sand dune frolicking. A highlight is the joy flight taken over the area. Returning to the city, the family enjoy a sunny day at ‘Luna Park’ with the wonderful rides and amusements on offer. Fred’s camera work on the ‘Scenic Railway’ in particular, shows his steady hand.

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film is mostly focused on the Snowy Mountains Scheme in New South Wales, an integrated water and hydro-electric power utility constructed between 1949 and 1974, located in Australia’s Southern Alps.

There are also some scenes of travel around Brisbane in Queensland.

Frequent title cards assist the viewer with detail, particularly regarding the workings of the hydro Scheme.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Snowy Mountain Scheme 1957’
00:00:22:00 the Snowy Mountain Authority buildings
00:00:44:00 title card ‘Guthega Dam’ followed by views of the dam
00:01:45:00 views of the accommodation buildings
00:02:00:00 title card ‘Guthega Power Station’
00:02:14:00 several views of a large cement pipeline
00:02:55:00 title card ‘Island Bend’
00:03:11:00 a four wheel drive vehicle at the site
00:03:19:00 a Pioneer Express bus waiting for passengers
00:03:22:00 sign ‘Snowy Mountain Lookout’ followed by wide vistas of the mountains
00:03:44:00 title card ‘Adaminaby Dam’
00:04:03:00 trucks working in a quarry and the clearance of trees for the workings of the Scheme
00:04:50:00 workers atop a tower construction
00:05:15:00 sign for the contractors, ‘Etudes Et Enterprises’ at the T.I. power station
00:05:31:00 title card ‘Tumut Ponds’
00:05:48:00 mouths of tunnels into the mountainsides
00:06:27:00 title card ‘Cabramurra’
00:07:41:00 title card ‘Cooma Airport’
00:07:45:00 airplane for Butler Air Transport
00:08:14:00 title card ‘Queensland 1957’
00:08:19:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:08:50:00 title card ‘Mt Coot-Tha’
00:09:14:00 title card ‘Brisbane River’, followed by views of the river
00:09:55:00 ‘Koalas at Lone Pine’ followed by a koala sitting on a dog’s back, and kangaroos
00:10:35:00 ‘Glasshouse Mountains’
00:11:00:00 ‘Long Island’ and a map of the coast of Queensland showing the location
00:11:20:00 beach scenes and an open four wheel drive modified to take passengers from small boats to the shore and on to the holiday huts
00:12:24:00 fishing scenes and wooden boxes full of fish
00:12:40:00 title card ‘Visit to South Molle’
00:13:57:00 title card ‘Visit to Happy Bay’ followed by views around the beach and bay area
00:16:08:00 title card ‘Departure of Guests’ and the holiday visitors are taken on the modified jeep to a small boat, bound for the ferry

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of different segments – a family reunion at Halls Gap in 1973 where we see typical barbeques of the era – a small round three legged hotplate and a ‘trough’ style both stacked with 1970’s barbeque fare – lots of lamb chops. We also see the fashions of the 1970’s in the velvets, flares, knee high socks and long hair. ‘Sandown Park with Jack Brabham’ introduces a segment of vintage racing cars and favourite car driver of the day, Jack Brabham signing autographs and smiling at the camera.

The film also includes some Moomba parade floats and marching girls, some city scenes of Melbourne and the Yarra Heliport and Ansett-ANA helicopter and finishes with some up close footage on the set of ‘World of Sport’, a very popular television sports show of the era featuring Lou Richards, Jack Dyer and Ron Casey among others.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993).The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a little of suburban life in Heathmont when it was first being developed. We see some examples of vintage cars as they were at the time. One of the residents is a young Ron Barassi of Australian Rules Football fame, and Victorian of the Year in 2009, who lived in Heathmont from 1957 to the late 1970s when he moved to St Kilda in Melbourne.

Indoor scenes of the family home show family members with some of their many pets a highlight of which is a game of table tennis with their pet cockatoo and cat.

The film includes a trip to the beach with some some great examples of vintage bathing suits.

Also seen in the film are the Gas and Fuel Corporation buildings on Flinders St which were built in 1967 and demolished in 1997 to make way for the current Federation Square in Melbourne.

Another glimpse of Melbourne’s history flashes across the family television screen - the logo for ‘Channel O’ which was the precursor to the current Channel 10 television station.

There is also a segment showing a small or home based packaging business for what appears to be health food products. The film ends with some travel scenes.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:34:00 Gas & Fuel building on the site of current Federation Square
00:01:49:00 Ron Barassi standing in front of his home
00:08:55:00 Ticka the cockatoo and the family cat play table tennis with the family
00:11:16:00 home based health food business in production at the kitchen table

This film shows a little of suburban life in Heathmont when it was first being developed. We see some examples of vintage cars as they were at the time. One of the residents is a young Ron Barassi of Australian Rules Football fame, and Victorian of the Year in 2009, who lived in Heathmont from 1957 to the late 1970s when he moved to St Kilda in Melbourne.

Indoor scenes of the family home show family members with some of their many pets a highlight of which is a game of table tennis with their pet cockatoo and cat.

The film includes a trip to the beach with some some great examples of vintage bathing suits.

Also seen in the film are the Gas and Fuel Corporation buildings on Flinders St which were built in 1967 and demolished in 1997 to make way for the current Federation Square in Melbourne.

Another glimpse of Melbourne’s history flashes across the family television screen - the logo for ‘Channel O’ which was the precursor to the current Channel 10 television station.

There is also a segment showing a small or home based packaging business for what appears to be health food products. The film ends with some travel scenes.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:34:00 Gas & Fuel building on the site of current Federation Square
00:01:49:00 Ron Barassi standing in front of his home
00:08:55:00 Ticka the cockatoo and the family cat play table tennis with the family
00:11:16:00 home based health food business in production at the kitchen table

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows rural Victoria footage around Omeo. It features excavation of, and images of, the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme including power station interiors and exteriors and dam footage. Also included are hobby farm images, of children and adults with calves and chickens and pet dogs and cats. There is footage of a man collecting cow manure from paddocks.

We see images of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with goats, horses, Ayrshire and Illawarra cattle, jinkers, floats, horse-drawn carts with advertising. There is also footage of children playing childhood games on the family farm – wheelbarrow races, chasey, ball games and piggy-backs.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of Hayes family life across the generations to include the grandchildren. The first segment is titled, ‘The Animals’ and features the family pets including dogs, calves, cows and the audacious cockatoo named Ticka, at home in suburban Heathmont in Melbourne’s outer east.

There are travel scenes of Narracan East, King River and the ‘Astor’ motel at Albury where Charles takes some dramatic footage of the Hume Weir. The family were keen tennis players and visited Albury at Easter so likely took part in the Albury Tennis Association competitions.

As well are some beach scenes at Point Leo, Golden Beach and Frankston where we see one of the dogs up to its neck in sand and some great examples of sixties bathing suits and sun hats.

The filmmaker shows some of the great cars at the time so that we see examples of 1960s and 1970s models. A brief segment from the Moomba Festival in Melbourne shows the ‘Frankston by the Sea’ song lyrics on one of the floats at the time.

Charles also shows the family’s involvement in tennis, trying out an early model Cortina car, and celebrating ‘Elinor’s 21st’ in white gloves and evening gowns and a display of the presents.

A particular feature of the film is the footage of ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd (now demolished to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river).

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:01:37:00 children with their dad in the water at the beach (good example of bathing fashion)
00:02:58:00 tennis match between mum and dad
00:04:29:00 car with caravan and family in bush camp setting
00:05:14:00 Austin car with family standing at the front talking and combing hair
00:05:58:00 children being pushed on swings in a park by their mother (good fashion and sunglasses references)
00:7:30:00 close-up of little girl’s face as she blows out her birthday candles and looks to camera
00:07:41:00 family in front of war memorial at Mount Macedon
00:08:36:00 steam train travelling on a country rail line
00:08:46:00 family looking out from a ferry window
00:08:52:00 kids on a roundabout at a playground
00:09:00:00 grandmother, mother and children sitting on a playground wall – the grandmother is shooting a water pistol.
00:09:08:00 children on playground roundabout and dad jumps on to join them
00:09:32:00 a koala sitting in a tree climbs to the top and looks down
00:09:45:00 family and friends stand in front of a picket fence (good example of family groups and fashion from the time)
00:10:01:00 wide shot as cars travel across the bridge to Phillip Island

00:10:14:00 POV from inside car as it drives over the Phillip Island bridge

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows the Hayes family on a holiday when they are young parents with their young daughters. The family travels to The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd), the coastal town of Warrnambool, and the Eildon Weir and Eildon Lake, all in Victoria, before heading to Sydney in New South Wales.

Scenes from a zoo at the time could be distressing to some viewers as contemporary zoological standards are very different to those of the early 1950s.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 children and their parents on board a carnival train ride and the young Hayes girls with enormous bows in their hair stand for the camera, one very unsure and one laughing
00:00:22:00 riding on top of an elephant and monkeys swinging in their cage, followed by goats, a glimpse of a hippopotamus, bears, swimming penguins and a pacing tiger
00:02:26:00 the young Hayes girls sit with their father on a bench
00:02:30:00 Mr and Mrs Hayes and one of the girls at a lookout over a mountain range, likely to be The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd) in Victoria
00:02:55:00 wandering along creeks and bush and near dramatic waterfalls
00:03:41:00 family members smile at the camera, some lovely sunglasses and one of the Hayes girls shows her tiny handbag to the camera
00:04:00:00 one of the children hand feeds a bottle of milk to a lamb before taking it for a walk on a lead followed by some horse riding lessons
00:04:52:00 a lovely country house set against the mountains in the immediate background and an array of 1940s to 1950s cars parked alongside
00:05:42:00 a sign ‘Silverband Falls’
00:06:07:00 hand feeding cows with food scraps
00:06:30:00 community races for children and adults
00:07:23:00 views of the Eildon Weir and boats on Lake Eildon
00:08:00:00 the girls sit on some used cable spools
00:08:23:00 a small candlelit memorial to King George VI
00:08:30:00 swimming in a pool while an airplane flies overhead
00:09:20:00 a large ferry and the Sydney Harbour Bridge from a distance and up-close followed by street scenes in Sydney
00:10:26:00 beachgoers on the sand, possibly at Manly in Sydney and a family and or friends gathering for the camera
00:11:10:00 views of Sydney’s older city buildings including the AWA building and tower (Amalgamated Wireless Australasia)
00:11:15:00 the koala enclosure at the zoo followed by more elephant rides
